Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Impacts of seagrass genetic and species diversity in the provision of ecosystem services

POR.DRECONTENT:
Laura Reynolds

EAPSI Japan Project Outcomes Report

 

            Seagrasses are submerged, flowering plants found around the world. These plants provide many valuable ecosystem services including improved water quality through sediment and nutrient filtration, high production rates, and a suitable habitat for a number of ecologically and economically important invertebrate, fish, and marine mammal species. There is some evidence genetically diverse assemblages of these plants provide more ecosystem services than less genetically diverse assemblages.

            Because seagrasses inhabit nearshore, shallow areas, they are often disturbed or destroyed by human activity: mostly nutrient and pollutant inputs into the water. These anthropogenic disturbances are resulting in large losses or seagrasses worldwide, and scientists are attempting to mitigate these losses through restoration.

            My dissertation work at the Virginia Coast Reserve LTER site has shown that restoration of eelgrass (Zostera marina) using seed maintains the genetic diversity of the donor meadows and that using a genetically diverse donor can increase both the diversity of the restoration and the amount of ecosystem services that restoration provides. That research has also shown that meadows maintain that diversity over time, as restorations age. This maintenance over time is important because it means that investments into making restorations genetically diverse will have impacts for many years into the future. However, work in other seagrass systems is contrary, showing instead that seagrasses lose diversity as they age.

            Through the EAPSI program, I traveled to Akkeshi Japan and sampled seagrass populations of different age classes. Akkeshi is an interesting complement to my work in Virginia, because both places are dominated by the same species and have similar pristine environments that are not heavily impacted by humans. Meadows in Akkeshi also did not show a decrease in diversity with meadow age.

            Previous research using a different seagrass species (Posidonia oceanica) suggested that older, more stable meadows will evolve with larger clones which are best suited for the environment. This dominance results in a loss of genetic diversity. These data have been used to understand Zostera marina meadows as well, but our surveys in Virginia and in Japan do not agree with this hypothesis. These plants are both seagrasses; however, I suggest that the plants act differently. Posidonia is a large bodied seagrass with lots of below ground tissue. Because of its increased below ground storage, it’s distribution is considered persistent, and it has the opportunity to produce clones. Zostera on the other hand is typically smaller (at least in VA) and has a higher above to below ground biomass ratio. It is often considered more ephemeral because it lacks a large below ground storage capacity and may rely more on sexual reproduciton. Because of the different life histories and growth strategies, the meadows dominated by each of the two plant species may age differently.

            Working in Japan helped me validate new hypotheses that I had derived though my dissertation research in Virginia. In addition, I gained a new set of mentors, colleges, and hopefully collaborators in the process.
